title: upgrade from 4.5.13 to 5.0.10: multiple issues
body:
system specs:
- fedora 19
- php v5.5.2
- apache v2.4.6
- mariadb
- all php dependencies installed and working
- server was running oc v4.5.13 just fine.
install steps:
removed prior owncloud v4.5.13 from systems and made sure the owncloud database no longer existed.
did fresh install of owncloud v5.0.10 per documentation.
did a database retore of oc data to mariadb.
reboot server.
went to oc with browser and upgrade process seemed to completed with no visible errors.

problems encountered:
* login as admin to admin see other user folders, this was not expected. can't navigate in to them
* truncated oc_filecache and oc_fscache (this seems to be a recommended practice on the oc forums when seeing other user folders)
* reboot
* login as admin do not see other user folders, this was expected.

* set max upload size to 2gb but oc will not allow upload of file of any size. complains file max reached.

* sharing by security user group does not work
- see previous users & security groups in oc admin
- shared folders appear like a picture file (you don't have write permissions here)
- go back to folder owner and name of security group for sharing is gone, put back in place and sharing works again.

* sharing by file does not work.
- shared files appear like a picture file (you don't have write permissions here)
- go back to owner of files, put back in place and sharing by file works again.

* sharing fies by link does not work.
- go back to owner of files, put back in place and sharing work again.

i have reported this same set of problems before on prior owncloud v5.x and never heard back from any developer(s) regarding more information or providing status. my prior issue was open for at least 3 months and for some reason it was closed. i never closed the issue. i would be more than happy to do more testing or provide additional information. 

i have posted this same issue before and have seen no action or received any developer feedback. are upgrades being seriously addressed?
